description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bf62f","text":"Protocol for automated Bar-Seq Library preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sm5e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4po0c","text":"This protocol prepares 96 DNA samples, representing 24 samples from 4 different timepoints,  for multiplexed Illumina sequencing. The process starts with two rounds of PCR, each followed by a bead-based cleanup. The first round of PCR attaches primers that serve as tags to identify the timepoint and sample (e.g., time-points 1-4 in the Pooled, Growth-Based Assay Protocol). The second round of PCR attaches flow-cell adapters required for Illumina sequencing. Following the PCR and cleanup steps, the protocol outlines a procedure for pooling all samples together to ensure balanced representation during sequencing. This process starts with quantifying each sample's DNA concentration and then diluting and pooling together samples from the same timepoint.  The pooled samples' concentrations are then measured, and a small quantity of each timepoint sample is run on a gel to ensure the cleanup process was successful. The final step is to dilute and pool of all timepoint samples into one multiplexed tube for subsequent Illumina sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"elp5q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a4qv8","text":"NOTES:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3c36k","text":"Before implementing this protocol, prepare the magnetic bead suspension following the Preparation of Sera-mag SpeedBeads protocol.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":86,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":86,"length":43}],"data":{}},{"key":"1id25","text":"This protocol should be implemented after the Automation Protocol for Plasmid DNA Extraction from E. coli protocol","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":46,"length":59}],"data":{}},{"key":"1ompm","text":"A fragment analyzer can also be used instead of a gel to determine if the PCR clean-up process was a success","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8iqn3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9g7ne","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"56DFAE7F72D24C7CAC556E2F3E43BDB5","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.261ge5r2jg47/v1"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"9E309913C53C4A1FAAB70C98B6C4E322","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/automation-protocol-for-plasmid-dna-extraction-fro-8epv514yjl1b/v1/materials"}}}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"cvcka","text":"The protocol outlined in this document was created as a part of the Pooled, Growth-Based Assays for Protein Function Measurements pipeline for Align to Innovate’s Open Dataset Initiative. Align to Innovate is a non-profit research organization operating under open science principles with the goal of improving science research with programmable experiments. The Open Datasets Initiative is working to accelerate community-driven science with the use of automated labs to pioneer robust data collection methods and curated, high-fidelity, public biological datasets amenable to machine learning. This work was supported by Align to Innovate’s Open Datasets Initiative which receives philanthropic funding in part from Griffin Catalyst.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":68,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Pooling for Sequencing - Measure each sample's input plasmid DNA Concentration
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a14mb","text":"Measure the DNA concentrations (Cn) for all input plasmid samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":33,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cjk7t","text":"Note: The expected concentration (Cn's) is typically between 5 ng/uL and 40 ng/uL, though some samples for time point 4, the final growth plate, may end up lower than that.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":35,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point's samples, calculate the samples' final pooling volumes (Vf)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f0iql","text":"Within each time point's samples (i.e., the 24 samples coming from each growth plate), identify the the four lowest-concentration samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":86}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point's samples, calculate the samples' final pooling volumes (Vf)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8aqih","text":"Calculate the mean of their concentrations in ng/µL, and define this concentration as the low concentration limit (Clow ) for that time point.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":116,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point's samples, calculate the samples' final pooling volumes (Vf)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cv954","text":"For each sample, use the DNA concentration in ng/µL (Cn) and the following equation to calculate the pooling volume (Vn) for each sample:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":54,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":118,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fo12","text":"Vn = Clow/(Cn + 0.1 ng/uL)*15 µL","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":1,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":6,"length":3},{"style":"sub","offset":12,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point's samples, calculate the samples' final pooling volumes (Vf)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1nucv","text":"For each sample, set the final pooling volume (Vf) based on the following conditions: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":48,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpvsc","text":"If Vn \u003c 4 µL, set Vf = 4 µL","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":4,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":19,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdn9d","text":"If Vn  \u003e 15 µL, set Vf  = 15 µL.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":4,"length":3},{"style":"sub","offset":21,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point, pool all samples and measure the pooled-DNA concentration
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2qkru","text":"Within each time point's samples (i.e., the 24 samples coming each growth plate), pool together all samples into one container according to their final pooling volumes (Vf's) and store the remaining un-pooled samples at -20C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":82},{"style":"sub","offset":170,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f07jm","text":"Note: This will give one pooled sample for each time-point (four pooled samples in total), each at a concentration of approximately 20 ng/uL and with a volume of 100 to 300 uL. This is much more DNA than is needed for sequencing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Within each time point, pool all samples and measure the pooled-DNA concentration
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8mkpd","text":"For each of the four pooled samples, re-measure the DNA concentration and then store them at -20C until the next step can be accomplished.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Dilute each time point's sample and pool all samples for sequencing
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8al84","text":"To prepare samples for the sequencing provider, follow their instructions for pre-made Illumina libraries. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":78,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7qpq","text":"Note: They usually give the sample requirements in molar concentration, typically 5 nmol/L, which is about 1 ng/uL for the BarSeq libraries. They usually require a minimum of 20 uL to 30 uL per lane of sequencing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"co1de","text":"As an example, using the numbers above, a sample protocol might be to dilute 5 µL of each pooled sample into nuclease-free water to a concentration of 1 ng/uL. This will give much more than the minimum required volume, but it avoids the extra variability from pipetting smaller volumes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Dilute each time point's sample and pool all samples for sequencing
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ev81p","text":"Combine the diluted time point samples to be run on the sequencer. In the following manner:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ak38f","text":"For the first run: start with a single lane of NovaSeq, with all four time points combined in equal proportions. Then, after analyzing that data, if you need more data, order a second lane and send a second sample with only time points 2-4.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ql8g","text":"For consecutive runs: order a single lane of NovaSeq with the combine the time points with the following ratios: ⅓:1:1:1 for time points 1-4.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Run 2nd PCR: using primers for Illumina multiplexing

steps.section: Run 2nd PCR: using primers for Illumina multiplexing

steps.section: Run 2nd PCR: using primers for Illumina multiplexing
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c2ihq","text":"Run PCR plate 2  (99 µL) using conditions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"981sr","text":"98 C for 60 s ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ea9l6","text":"15 Cycles at:","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4sd0","text":"98 C for 10 s ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8p9nf","text":"72 C for 30 s ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"af1of","text":"3. 72 C for 120 s ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b4q6","text":"4. 10 C for 20 s ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"db602","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hl35","text":"Note: during the 2nd PCR run, throw Midi plate 2 to waste and prepare Midi plate 3 following the instructions below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Run 2nd PCR: using primers for Illumina multiplexing
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4cbuv","text":"Prepare PCR plate 2 by pipetting 54 uL of 2x master mix (containing both forward and reverse universal primers for Illumina sequencing) into each well","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Run 2nd PCR: using primers for Illumina multiplexing

steps.section: Quantify the amount of amplified DNA
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2etj0","text":"The amount of amplified DNA should also be measured for each sample at each time point using Qubit or an equivalent DNA quantitative measurement. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fceb5","text":"Expected yields are between 10 ng/uL and 30 ng/uL (in 45 uL), though some samples could have as little as 1 ng/uL (e.g., samples grown with the highest antibiotic concentration at the later time points).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Run a gel for each time point
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"rs05","text":"Run a gel for each time point, and compared these results with those obtained during BarSeq method development. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eegqt","text":"The gels should not have any visible bands that are shorter than the expected amplicon size (315 bp)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qm2f","text":"Shorter bands indicate incomplete PCR cleanup that could result in a very low sequence count from Illumina sequencing.
